citations.narrative:
During this inspection, unattended periods of public contact were observed with one group of patrons interacting with a
free-roaming goat on exhibit. While responsible, readily-identifiable attendants were present at the facility, neither
attendant was in viewing site to oversee the patrons petting the goat, as they were attending to another animal enclosure.
Oversight of public contact is necessary to safeguard animal encounters and prevent injuries to the public and animals on
exhibit. The facility must ensure that a responsible, knowledgeable, and readily identifiable employee or attendant is
present at all times during periods of public contact.

The free-roaming goats, white-tailed deer, chickens, and ducks have access to a public barrier that is in disrepair. A gap
in the barrier fencing adjacent to the chicken coop had a hole measuring 11.5 inches wide and 17.5 inches tall. The torn
fencing has wire that is now coiled outward with exposed sharp points, causing the wire to curl up and lift off the ground.
Compromised structural integrity within primary enclosures can provide an opportunity for entrapment or injury to the
animals contained therein. Outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to
protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals.

Upon inspection, the refrigerator storing perishable food items for the animals needed cleaning. The left drawer at the
bottom of the fridge had excessive debris, brown residue, and buildup within the drawer itself, as well as the surfaces
directly below it.
Failure to store food items in cleaned and sanitized areas can result in food compromise, contamination, or attract pests
that harbor disease to these areas.
All supplies of food and bedding shall be stored in a manner that adequately protects against deterioration, molding or
contamination by vermin.

Multiple areas along the perimeter fence no longer stand at six feet tall. Upon today’s inspection, the northeast side of the
fence line now measures 67 inches tall. The gate along the west side of the perimeter fence and fence line along the
northwest side of the facility measures 69 inches and 47.5 inches, respectively. Though the facility representative has
been working to update the perimeter fence, construction is still ongoing and these areas were not completed by today’s
inspection as planned.
Having a perimeter fence in place protects the animals in the facility by restricting animals and unauthorized persons from
going through it or under it, permitting contact with the animals in the facility. Additionally, it serves as a secondary
containment system for the animals in the facility. The perimeter fence must be of sufficient distance from the outside of
the primary enclosure to prevent physical contact between animals inside the enclosure and animals or persons outside
the perimeter fence. Non-dangerous animals housed in outdoor facilities require a 6-foot-tall perimeter fence around their
enclosure and must be at least 3-feet away from any enclosures or buildings, unless an approved variance has been
issued in writing by the Administrator.

An opened container of peanut butter spread used for enrichment items for the gray squirrel has expired, It is kept with
other food items that are fed to the animals at the facility. Feeding food items beyond its expiration date prevents the
facility from ensuring that the nutritive value has been upheld and preserved. Food shall be wholesome, palatable, and
free from contamination and of sufficient quantity and nutritive value to maintain all animals in good health.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The outdoor enclosure housing chickens at the facility have several cobwebs encompassing the entire primary enclosure
along the ceiling, corners, and ledges. The span of the cobwebs suggest they’ve remained uninterrupted for months,
amidst routine husbandry practices performed at the facility. Failure to clean all areas of the enclosures enable grounds
for bugs, insects, and other pests to thrive within the housing areas. Premises where housing facilities are located,
including buildings, surrounding grounds, and exhibit areas, must be kept clean and in good repair to protect the birds
from disease, and to facilitate the husbandry practices required in this subpart that reduce or eliminate breeding and living
areas for rodents, pests, and vermin.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by December 30th, 2023, or the applicant will forfeit the
license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License
Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
